item.title: Polycube gRPC service libraries
item.description:
üåê polycube-grpc-service-libraries üîó

polycube-grpc-service-libraries allows the creation of stand-alone Polycube services in various programming languages using gRPC.

Polycube services, called cubes, can be composed to build arbitrary service chains, enabling custom network connectivity for:

  • Namespaces
  • Containers
  • Virtual machines (VMs)
  • Physical hosts

üõ† My Work in Brief üîó

I developed an architecture that allows the creation of network services in Polycube using languages like:

  • Go
  • Python
  • C++
  • Other gRPC-supported languages

Why gRPC?
gRPC was chosen because it enables running the control plane of a service on a remote machine, separate from where the data plane is running. This design improves flexibility and scalability.

item.title: Crownlabs
item.description:
üë®‚Äçüíª CrownLabs: Remote Computing Labs üîó

CrownLabs is a set of services designed to deliver remote computing labs through per-user environments based on:

  • Virtual machines (VMs)
  • Lightweight containers

This service was set up in about three weeks by a group of MSc students from the Polytechnic Institute of Turin (Italy) under the pressure of COVID-19 in March 2020.

CrownLabs is currently developed, maintained, and operated by a group of volunteers, mainly MSc students in Computer Engineering at the Polytechnic of Turin.

item.title: Polycube
item.description:
üî∑ Polycube: Open-Source Network Framework üîó

Polycube is an open-source software framework that provides fast and lightweight network functions such as:

  • Bridges
  • Routers
  • Firewalls
  • Other network services

Polycube services, called cubes, can be composed to build arbitrary service chains, enabling custom network connectivity for:

  • Namespaces
  • Containers
  • Virtual machines (VMs)
  • Physical hosts

üõ† My Work in Brief üîó

üìä Introducing Custom Metrics üîó

I focused on implementing custom metrics, defined in the YANG model of each service. These metrics are collected and exposed via the /metrics endpoint, which is later read by Prometheus.
